column1: A concussion is an injury to the brain that is caused by a sudden
column3: typically because of a blow or jolt to the head or body that makes the brain move rapidly inside the skull.The injury that results from this is called a mild traumatic brain injury
column4: most commonly referred to as a concussion. There are many different definitions of concussion
column5: but they all have some things in common. These common features include changes in brain function
column6: including changes in the way you think (cognitive changes)
column7: in the way your brain works (neurological changes)
column8: and in the way you feel (physical and emotional changes). These changes may or may not be accompanied by a temporary loss of consciousness
column9: also known as fainting or passing out. The abrupt movement of the brain can stretch and injure brain cells
column10: which can change the way these cells function. These changes can be short-lived or long-lived
column12: the cells heal and function normally in 7–10 days.Sometimes
column13: it may take longer than 10 days for the brain to return to normal after a concussion
